Original question: Larry the Very Subprime Lender gives loans of size $10,000. In 25 percent of cases, the borrower pays back the loan quickly with no interest or fees. In 50 percent of cases, the borrower disappears (moves away, declares bankruptcy, dies) without paying anything. In 25 percent of cases, the borrower pays back the loan slowly and — after years of ballooning interest payments, hefty fees, etc. — pays Larry a total of $100,000. However, in this scenario, Larry has to give $60,000 to third parties (repo services, foreclosure lawyers, eviction teams, bill collectors, etc.) in order to get the borrower to pay the $100,000. Compute the expectation of the net amount a given borrower ends up paying (i.e., amount paid minus amount borrowed).
